The high point of Italian emigration was 1913, when 872,598 persons left Italy. Starting from the last two decades of the nineteenth century, Italy developed into a colonial power by forcing Somalia, Eritrea and later Libya and the Dodecanese under its rule. During World War I, Italy at first stayed neutral but in 1915 signed the Treaty of London, entering Entente on the promise of receiving Trento, Trieste, Istria, Dalmatia and parts of Ottoman Empire. During the war, 600,000 Italians died, and the economy collapsed. Under the Peace Treaty of Saint-Germain, Italy obtained just Bolzano-Bozen, Trento, Trieste and Istria in a victory described as "mutilated" by the public.[PARAGRAPH:2]The turbulence that followed the devastation of World War I, inspired by the Russian Revolution, led to turmoil and anarchy. The liberal establishment, fearing a socialist revolution, started to endorse the small National Fascist Party, led by Benito Mussolini. In October 1922 the fascists attempted a coup (the Marcia su Roma, "March on Rome"), but the king ordered the army not to intervene, instead forming an alliance with Mussolini. Over the next few years, Mussolini banned all political parties and curtailed personal liberties, thus forming a dictatorship. In 1935, Mussolini subjugated Ethiopia after a surprisingly lengthy campaign. This resulted in international alienation and the exodus of the country from the League of Nations. A first pact with Nazi Germany was concluded in 1936, and a second in 1938. Italy strongly supported Franco in the Spanish civil war. The country was opposed to Adolf Hitler's annexations of Austria, but did not interfere with it. Italy supported Germany's annexation of Sudetenland, however.[PARAGRAPH:2]On 7 April 1939 Italy occupied Albania, a de facto protectorate for decades, and entered World War II in 1940, taking part in the late stages of the Battle of France. Mussolini, wanting a quick victory like Hitler's blitzkriegs in Poland and France, invaded Greece in October 1940 via Albania but was forced to accept a humiliating defeat after a few months. At the same time, Italy, after initially conquering British Somalia, saw an allied counter-attack lead to the loss of all possessions in the Horn of Africa. Italy was also defeated by British forces in North Africa and was only saved by the urgently dispatched German Africa Corps led by Erwin Rommel. Italy was invaded by the Allies in June 1943, leading to the collapse of the fascist regime and the arrest of Mussolini. In September 1943, Italy surrendered. The country remained a battlefield for the rest of the war, as the allies were moving up from the south and the north was the base for loyalist Italian fascist and German Nazi forces. The whole picture became more complex by the activity of the Italian partisans; see Italian resistance movement. The Nazis left the country on 25 April 1945. This led to the eventual disbanding of Italian fascist forces.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1946, Vittorio Emanuele III's son, Umberto II, was forced to abdicate. Italy became a republic after a referendum held on 2 June 1946, a day celebrated since as Republic Day. This was the first election in Italy allowing women to vote. The Republican Constitution was approved and came into force on 1 January 1948. Under the Paris Peace Treaties of 1947, the eastern border area was lost to Yugoslavia, and, later, the free territory of Trieste was divided between the two states. Fears in the Italian electorate of a possible Communist takeover proved crucial for the first universal suffrage electoral outcome on the 18th of April 1948 when the Democrazia Cristiana, under the undisputed leadership of Alcide De Gasperi, won a resounding victory with 48 percent of the vote. In the 50s Italy became a member of the NATO alliance and an ally of the United States, which helped to revive the Italian economy through the Marshall Plan: until the 60s the country saw a period of prolonged economic growth termed the "Economic Miracle". In 1957, Italy was a signatory to the Treaties of Rome founding the European Economic Community (EEC), which became the European Union (EU) in 1993.[PARAGRAPH:2]From the late 1960s till late 1980s the country experienced a hard economic crisis and the Years of Lead, a period characterised by widespread social conflicts and terrorist acts carried out by extra-parliamentary movements. The Years of Lead culminated in the assassination of the Christian Democracy (DC) leader Aldo Moro in 1978, bringing to an end the "Historic Compromise" between the DC and the Communist Party. In the 1980s, for the first time since 1945, two governments were led by non-Christian-Democrat premiers: a republican (Giovanni Spadolini) and a socialist (Bettino Craxi); the DC remained, however, the main force supporting the government. The Socialist Party (PSI), led by Bettino Craxi, became more and more critical of the Communists and of the Soviet Union; Craxi himself pushed in favour of US president Ronald Reagan's positioning of Pershing missiles in Italy, a move the Communists hotly contested.[PARAGRAPH:2]From 1992 to 2009, Italy faced significant challenges, as voters, disenchanted with past political paralysis, massive government debt, extensive corruption, and organized crime's considerable influence (collectively called Tangentopoli after being uncovered by Mani pulite - "Clean hands") demanded political, economic, and ethical reforms. The scandals involved all major parties, but especially those in the government coalition: between 1992 and 1994 the DC underwent a severe crisis and was dissolved, splitting up into several pieces, while the PSI and the other governing minor parties completely dissolved. The 1994 elections put media magnate Silvio Berlusconi into the Prime Minister's seat. However, he was forced to step down in December when the Lega Nord Party withdrew its support. In April 1996, national elections led to the victory of a centre-left coalition under the leadership of Romano Prodi. Prodi's first government became the third-longest to stay in power before he narrowly lost a vote of confidence, by three votes, in October 1998. A new government was formed by Massimo D'Alema, but in April 2000 he resigned. In 2001, national elections led to the victory of a centre-right coalition under the leadership of Silvio Berlusconi, the centre-right formed a government, and Silvio Berlusconi was able to remain in power for a complete five-year mandate, but with two different governments. The first one (2001–2005) became the longest-lived government in post-war Italy. Italy participated in the US-led military coalition in Iraq. The elections in 2006 were won by the centre-left, allowing Prodi to form his second government, but in early 2008 he resigned because of the collapse of his coalition. In the ensuing new early elections in April 2008, Silvio Berlusconi won to form a government for a fourth time.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Khmer Empire was a kingdom located in Southeast Asia from 790 until 1431 AD. At its height, the Khmer Empire covered fully one half of Southeast Asia, encompassing what is today Cambodia, Laos, Thailand and parts of Myanmar.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Khmer Empire was founded on the remnants of the kingdom of Chenla, which had spread itself across much of Cambodia and Laos, but had become fractured and weakened by the eighth century AD. A former Chenla prince, Jayvaraman II, returned to the area after his education in Java and created the base of power for the Khmer Empire in the region that is today central Cambodia.[PARAGRAPH:2]The fractured state of Southeast Asia after the collapse of Chenla made the unified strength of the Khmer a welcome presence in the region. The new nation quickly annexed many of its smaller neighbors, sometimes peacefully, sometimes less so.[PARAGRAPH:2]As their prominence grew, the Khmer kings initiated many grand public works projects. King Yasovarman I, ruling from 889 to 915, built Yasodharapura, the first major capital of the Khmer, on a site that would remain important throughout Khmer history. Yasovarman also constructed the East Baray, a massive raised reservoir that was capable of holding over 60 million cubic meters of water.[PARAGRAPH:2]Not long after Yasovarman's reign, internal struggles began to sweep the Khmer Empire. And while a number of impressive works of construction were completed during this period, it was not until the reign of Jayavarman V, from 968 to 1001 that the Khmer Empire could again find itself in relative peace. And it would still be another century until Suryavarman II would again make the Khmer a force to be reckoned with.[PARAGRAPH:2]Ascending to the throne in 1113, Suryavarman II established himself as a firm ruler over the squabbling princes that wreaked havoc on the reign of his father, Suryavarman I. Wisely guiding the forces within his nation, Suryavarman the younger would turn the Khmer Empire into the most powerful kingdom in southeast Asia. Extending his domain over much of neighboring Thailand and Myanmar and constructing Angkor Wat, a monumental temple complex erected not far from the site of the original Khmer capital of Yasodharapura, Suryavarman would guide his Empire to its greatest heights.[PARAGRAPH:2]Shortly after the death of Suryavarman in 1150, relations would sour between the Khmer and the Champa Empire, former allies of the Khmer, and would lead to the sacking of Angkor Wat in 1177, nearly drawing to an end the reign of the Khmer kingdom. The kingdom would be given one last flourish under the reign of Jayavarman VII, whose keen military insight brought the Champa under Khmer control. A devout Buddhist, Jayavarman also littered the Cambodian countryside with new temples.[PARAGRAPH:2]Jayavarman's reign would mark the end of the powerful rulers of the Khmer. A Thai uprising established the kingdom of Ayutthaya in 1350, which would eventually absorb all that once was the Khmer Empire within its borders by 1431.
TEXT.French: L'empire khmer est un royaume situé en Asie du sud entre 790 et 1431 ap. J.C. A son apogée, l'empire khmer couvre entièrement la moitié de l'Asie du sud, comprenant ce qui est aujourd'hui le Cambodge, le Laos, la Thaïlande et certaines régions du Myanmar.[PARAGRAPH:1]L'empire khmer est fondé sur les ruines du royaume de Chenla, qui s'est étendu sur une grande partie du Cambodge et du Laos, mais s'est retrouvé divisé et affaibli à l'aube du huitième siècle. Ancien prince du Chenla, Jayvaraman II revient dans la région après avoir été éduqué à Java et crée la base de la puissance khmère dans la région qui est aujourd'hui le centre du Cambodge.[PARAGRAPH:1]L'état de division dans lequel se trouve l'Asie du sud après la chute du Chenla fait de la nation khmère unifiée une présence appréciée dans la région. La nouvelle nation annexe rapidement ses petits voisins, parfois pacifiquement, parfois non.[PARAGRAPH:1]Tandis que leur prééminence grandit, les rois khmers initient de grands projets de travaux publics. Le roi Yasovarman Ier, qui règne de 889 à 915, fonde Yasodharapura, la première grande capitale khmère, sur un site qui restera important tout au long de l'histoire khmère. Yasovarman construit aussi le baray est, immense réservoir capable de recueillir plus de 60 millions de mètres cube d'eau.[PARAGRAPH:1]Peu de temps après le règne de Yasovarman, l'empire khmer est en proie à des luttes internes. Plusieurs grands édifices sont érigés pendant cette période mais il faut attendre le règne de Jayavarman V, de 968 à 1001, pour que l'empire khmer retrouve une paix relative. Et ce n'est qu'un siècle plus tard que Suryavarman II parviendra à faire des Khmers une force non négligeable.[PARAGRAPH:1]Suryavarman II accède au trône en 1113 et prend l'ascendant sur les princes qui avaient totalement désorganisé le règne de son père Suryavarman I. Suryavarman sait guider son peuple avec sagesse et fait de l'empire khmer le royaume le plus puissant de l'Asie du sud-est. Etendant son domaine sur une grande partie de la Thaïlande et du Myanmar, et construisant le temple monumental érigé non loin du site de la première capitale khmère, Yasodharapura, Suryavarman conduit son empire à son apogée.[PARAGRAPH:1]Peu après la mort de Suryavarman en 1150, les relations entre les empires khmer et champa s'enveniment, ce qui conduit au sac d'Angkor Vat en 1177, lequel manque de mettre un terme au règne du royaume khmer. Le royaume va connaître une dernière ère de prospérité sous le règne de Jayavarman VII, dont les troupes parviennent à ramener le Champa sous contrôle khmer. Fervent bouddhiste, Jayavarman construit également pléthore de nouveaux temples.[PARAGRAPH:1]Le règne de Jayavarman va marquer la fin des puissants chefs khmers. Une révolte thaï établit le royaume d'Ayutthaya en 1350, qui, en 1431, finit par absorber à l'intérieur de ses frontières tout ce qui formait jadis le puissant empire khmer.
TEXT.German: Das Reich der Khmer war ein von 790 bis 1431 n. Chr. bestehendes Königreich in Südostasien. Zu seiner Blütezeit bedeckte das Reich der Khmer die Hälfte Südostasiens und umfasste das heutige Kambodscha, Laos, Thailand und Teile Myanmars.[PARAGRAPH:1]Das Reich der Khmer gründete sich auf die Überreste des Königreichs von Chenla, das einst den Großteil von Kambodscha und Laos bedeckt hatte, jedoch im 8. Jahrhundert n. Chr. zersplittert war. Ein ehemaliger Prinz aus Chenla, Jayavarman II., kehrte nach seiner Erziehung auf Java zurück und schuf die Machtgrundlage für das Reich der Khmer auf dem Gebiet des heutigen Kambodscha.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nach der Zersplitterung Südostasiens, die auf den Zusammenbruch Chenlas folgte, war die vereinigte Stärke der Khmer in der Region willkommen. Die neue Nation annektierte rasch viele ihrer kleineren Nachbarn, manchmal friedlich, manchmal weniger friedlich.[PARAGRAPH:1]Mit wachsender Bedeutung ließen die Könige der Khmer viele großartige öffentliche Bauwerke errichten. König Yasovarman I., der von 889 bis 915 herrschte, baute Yasodharapura, die erste große Hauptstadt der Khmer, an einer Stelle, die im ganzen Verlauf der Geschichte der Khmer bedeutend bleiben würde. Yasovarman errichtete auch den Ost-Baray, ein gewaltiges erhöhtes Wasserbecken, das 60 Millionen Kubikmeter Wasser fassen konnte.[PARAGRAPH:1]Kurz nach dem Ende der Herrschaft Yasovarmans begannen innere Kämpfe, das Reich der Khmer zu erschüttern. Zwar wurden in dieser Zeit eine Reihe beeindruckender Bauten fertiggestellt, doch erst unter der Herrschaft Jayavarmans V., von 968 bis 1001, erlebte das Reich der Khmer wieder relativen Frieden. Und bis Suryavarman II. die Khmer wieder zu einer nicht zu unterschätzenden Macht formen sollte, sollte noch ein weiteres Jahrhundert vergehen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Suryavarman II. bestieg den Thron im Jahr 1113 und etablierte sich als strenger Herrscher über die zankenden Prinzen, die die Herrschaft seines Vaters, Suryavarmans I., ins Chaos gestürzt hatten. Suryavarman der Jüngere leitete die Kräfte innerhalb seines Volkes weise an und verwandelte das Reich der Khmer in das mächtigste Königreich Südostasiens. Suryavarman erweiterte seinen Einflussbereich über einen Großteil des benachbarten Thailands und Myanmars hinaus, errichtete Angkor Wat, eine monumentale Tempelanlage nicht weit vom Originalstandort der Khmer-Hauptstadt unter Yasodharapura, und führte so sein Reich in die Blütezeit.[PARAGRAPH:1]Kurz nach dem Tod Suryavarmans 1150 kühlten die Beziehungen zwischen den Khmer und dem Reich der Champa, den ehemaligen Verbündeten der Khmer, ab und Angkor Wat wurde 1177 geplündert und das Königreich der Khmer beinahe vernichtet. Unter Jayavarman VII., dessen scharfer militärischer Verstand die Champa unter Kontrolle durch die Khmer brachte, erlebte das Königreich eine letzte Blüte. Als frommer Buddhist überzog Jayavarman die Landschaft in Kambodscha auch mit neuen Tempeln.[PARAGRAPH:1]Jayavarmans Herrschaft sollte das Ende der mächtigen Khmer-Herrscher sein. Aus einem Aufstand der Thai ging 1350 das Königreich Ayutthaya hervor, das 1431 alles umfassen sollte, was sich einst innerhalb der Grenzen des Khmer-Reichs befand.
TEXT.Italian: L'Impero Khmer era un regno che si estese nel sudest asiatico dal 790 al 1431 d.C. Al massimo del suo splendore, l'Impero Khmer copriva interamente metà del sudest asiatico, comprendendo quelli che sono gli attuali Cambogia, Laos, Tailandia e parte del Myanmar.[PARAGRAPH:1]L'Impero Khmer fu fondato sui resti del regno di Chanla, che si estendeva su gran parte di Cambogia e Laos ma che, nell'ottavo secolo d.C., si era sgretolato e indebolito. Jayvaraman II, un tempo principe Chenla, tornò in zona dopo aver ricevuto la propria educazione a Giava e creò la base di potere per l'Impero Khmer nella regione che è oggi il centro della Cambogia.[PARAGRAPH:1]La suddivisione del sudest asiatico dopo la caduta di Chenla rese la forze unificate dei Khmer una presenza benvenuta nella regione. La nuova nazione annesse rapidamente molte di quelle vicine, a volte in pace, altre no.[PARAGRAPH:1]Con l'aumentare della loro importanza, i re Khmer avviarono molti grandi progetti pubblici. Re Yashovarman I, che regnò dall'889 al 915, costruì Yasodharapura, la prima grande capitale Khmer, in una località che rimarrà importante durante tutta la storia dei Khmer. Yashovarman costruì anche il Baray orientale, un gigantesco serbatoio rialzato in grado di contenere più di 60 milioni di metri cubi d'acqua.[PARAGRAPH:1]Non molto dopo il regno di Yashovarman, si manifestarono delle lotte intestine all'Impero Khmer. E, pur essendo state portate a termine molte costruzioni impressionanti in questo periodo, l'Impero Khmer dovette aspettare il regno di Jayvarman V, dal 968 al 1001, per conoscere un periodo di relativa pace. E sarebbe dovuto passare un altro secolo, prima che Suryavarman II rendesse nuovamente i Khmer una forza temibile.[PARAGRAPH:1]Salito al trono nel 1113, Suryavarman II si affermò come fermo sovrano sui litigiosi principi che devastarono il regno di suo padre, Suryavarman I. Guidando con saggezza le forze della nazione, il giovane Suryavarman trasformò l'Impero Khmer nel regno più potente del sudest asiatico. Estese il proprio dominio su gran parte dei vicini Tailandia e Myanmar e costruì Angkor Vat, un tempio monumentale eretto a non molta distanza dal luogo dove era sorta l'originaria capitale Khmer, Yasodharapura; Suryavarman avrebbe portato l'Impero alle più alte vette di splendore.[PARAGRAPH:1]Poco dopo la morte di Suryavarman, nel 1150, le relazioni tra l'Impero Khmer e quello Champa, ex alleati, si deteriorarono: la situazione sfociò nel sacco di Angkor Vat del 1177 e quasi causò la fine del regno Khmer. L'Impero si riprese un'ultima volta sotto la guida di Jayavarman VII, il cui acuto intuito militare gli permise di assumere il controllo dei Champa. Jayavarman era un devoto buddista e disseminò la campagna cambogiana di nuovi templi.[PARAGRAPH:1]Jayavarman fu l'ultimo dei potenti leader dei Khmer. Nel 1350 una rivolta Thai diede vita al regno di Ayutthaya, che attorno al 1431 assorbì nei propri confini quello che era l'Impero Khmer.
TEXT.Spanish: El imperio jémer fue un reino del sudeste asiático que existió entre los años 790 y 1431 d. C. En su momento álgido, el imperio se extendía sobre la mitad entera del sudeste asiático e incluía las actuales Camboya, Laos y Tailandia, además de parte de Birmania.[PARAGRAPH:1]Este imperio nació de las cenizas del reino de Chenla que había ocupado la mayor parte de Camboya y Laos, pero había sufrido un proceso de fractura y decadencia a lo largo del siglo VIII d. C. Jayvaraman II, un príncipe del desaparecido reino de Chenla, volvió a la zona tras recibir su educación en Java, y se dedicó a crear la base de poder del futuro imperio en la región que hoy en día es el centro de Camboya.[PARAGRAPH:1]El estado de desintegración en el que estaba sumido el sudeste asiático tras el colapso de Chenla provocó que la fuerza unificadora representada por los jémeres fuera bien recibida en la región. La nueva nación se anexionó rápidamente muchos de los estados más pequeños, algunos por medios pacíficos y otros no tanto.[PARAGRAPH:1]A medida que iba creciendo, el imperio jémer llevó a cabo una campaña de obras públicas. El rey Yasovarman I, que gobernó entre los años 889 y 915, construyó Yasodharapura, la primera capital importante de los jémeres, en un lugar que seguiría siendo muy importante durante toda su historia. Yasovarman también construyó el Baray del este, un enorme depósito de agua capaz de almacenar más de 60 millones de metros cúbicos de agua.[PARAGRAPH:1]Poco después del reinado de Yasovarman, la disidencia interna empezó a sacudir el imperio jémer. Y, aunque durante este período se completó un impresionante número de construcciones, el imperio jémer no volvió a encontrarse en un estado de relativa paz hasta el reinado de Jayavarman V (968_1001). Aun así, tendría que pasar un siglo más para que Suryavarman II volviera a convertir a los jémeres en una potencia a tener en cuenta.[PARAGRAPH:1]Tras ascender al trono en 1113, Suryavarman II consolidó su posición como soberano, por encima de todos los príncipes que habían sembrado el caos durante el reinado de su padre, Suryavarman I. Gracias a sus inteligentes medidas de gobierno, Suryavarman, llamado el Joven, convertiría el imperio jémer en el reino más poderoso del sudeste asiático. Además de extender sus dominios sobre Tailandia y Birmania y construir Angkor Wat (un monumental complejo de templos situado no muy lejos de la capital original de los jémeres, Yasodharapura), Suryavarman llevaría el imperio al pináculo de su gloria.[PARAGRAPH:1]Poco después de su muerte (1150), las relaciones entre el imperio jémer y el imperio de Champa, antiguos aliados, empezaron a agriarse hasta desembocar en el saqueo de Angkor Wat (1177), que estuvo a punto de significar la desaparición del imperio jémer. El reino viviría un último florecimiento bajo el reinado de Jayavarman VII, cuya destreza militar permitiría someter al reino de Champa. Además, Jayavarman, devoto budista, sembró el territorio camboyano de nuevos templos.[PARAGRAPH:1]Jayavarman sería el último de los reyes fuertes del imperio jémer. Un levantamiento tailandés desembocó en el establecimiento del reino de Ayutthaya (1350), que terminaría de absorber todos los territorios jémeres en 1431.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Kingdom of Kongo was a former state in western Central Africa, founded in the 14th century. In the 15th century the kingdom stretched from the Congo River in the north to the Loje River in the south and from the Atlantic Ocean in the west to beyond the Kwango River in the east. Several smaller autonomous states to the south and east paid tribute to it. Kongo was ruled by the manikongo, or king, and was divided into six provinces, each administered by a governor appointed by the manikongo.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1482, Diogo C�o, a Portuguese explorer, visited the kingdom, and the reigning manikongo, Nzinga Nkuwu, was favorably impressed with Portuguese culture. In 1491, Portuguese missionaries, soldiers, and artisans were welcomed at Mbanza-Kongo, the capital of the kingdom. The missionaries soon gained converts, including Nzinga Nkuwu (who took the name Jo�o I), and the soldiers helped the manikongo defeat an internal rebellion.[PARAGRAPH:2]The next manikongo, Afonso I (reigned 1505�43), was raised as a Christian and attempted to convert the kingdom to Christianity and European ways. However, the Portuguese residents in Kongo were primarily interested in increasing their private fortunes (especially through capturing Africans and selling them into slavery), and, despite the attempts of King Manuel I of Portugal to channel the efforts of his subjects into constructive projects, the continued rapaciousness of the Portuguese played a major part in weakening the kingdom and reducing the hold of the capital over the provinces.[PARAGRAPH:2]After the death of Afonso, Kongo declined rapidly and suffered major civil wars. The Portuguese shifted their interest southward to the kingdom of Ndongo and helped Ndongo defeat Kongo in 1556. However, in 1569 the Portuguese aided Kongo by helping to repel an invasion from the east by a Lunda ethnic group. The slave trade, which undermined the social structure of Kongo, continued to weaken the authority of the manikongo.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1641, Manikongo Garcia II allied himself with the Dutch in an attempt to control Portuguese slave traders, but in 1665 a Portuguese force decisively defeated the army of Kongo and from that time onward the manikongo was little more than a vassal of Portugal. The kingdom disintegrated into a number of small states, all controlled to varying degrees by the Portuguese. The area of Kongo was incorporated mostly into Portuguese Angola and partly into the Kongo Free State (under control of Belgium). Today the territory is made up by Northern Angola, the western part of the Democratic Republic of Congo (Congo-Kinshasa, former Zaire) and southern Republic of the Congo (Congo-Brazzaville).

[TAB]The Mayan Empire blossomed within the thick jungles and volcanic hills of Belize, Guatemala and the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico. Creators of the most advanced civilization in the Americas from 700 BC until 900 AD, the Mayan population in its age was second only to the Chinese T'ang dynasty in sheer numbers.[PARAGRAPH:2]Often referred to as the "Greeks of the New World," the Mayans were similarly organized into a series of feuding city states, although these cities served more religious and administrative purposes than as populations centers. Uniting the Maya culture was a common language, religion and artistic style, but each city state remained fiercely independent, often uniting only at the point of a Holkan spear. [PARAGRAPH:2]Every city-state was governed by its own royal family, whom often claimed full or semi-divinity. During the Mayan Classical Period from roughly 250 to 900 AD, these cities became vast complexes of pyramids, causeways and plazas. Nakbe, the first city-state to grow on a grand scale, began its expansion around 700 BC. By 300 BC, Nakbe had been transformed into an impressive city, with four grand step pyramids and a seven mile stone causeway linking it to the nearby city of El Mirador. [PARAGRAPH:2]Nakbe was only the first of many vast cities. Chichen Itza, Tikal and Palenque all became massive population centers. With myriad pyramids and religious structures, Tikal grew to become a city of the grandest scale and the largest of the Mayan population centers, dwarfing Palenque and Copan.[PARAGRAPH:2]Palenque, a significantly smaller settlement to the West, reached its zenith in the seventh century AD under the reign of Pacal II, whose subjugation of neighboring cities ensured the hegemony of his own. Much is known about Pacal and his city thanks to the intricately-carved history left to us within Pacal's tomb, "The Temple of Inscriptions," entire walls of which were filled with the Mayans' distinctive pictographic language, the only written language developed in the Americas. [PARAGRAPH:2]Language was not the only realm in which Mayan minds excelled. Their calendars were nearly on par with those of the modern era, but were created without the use of the telescope or other tools. Independent development of the number zero, an accomplishment that eluded both the Greeks and Romans, was yet another of the impressive feats of the Mayans. [PARAGRAPH:2]Most of these discoveries grew out of the Mayan religion. And while certainly interested in knowledge, the Mayan religion was ensconced in the belief of the power of blood. Many wars among the Maya were fought simply to provide prisoners to be sacrificed in intricate religious ceremonies, thought necessary to ensure the safety and advancement of the people. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Mayan civilization came to a surprisingly abrupt end, and the cause of this fall is still a hotly debated topic. One of the most widely-accepted theories is that the delicate ecology of the Yucatan rainforests simply could no longer support the growing population of the Mayan people. A peasant revolt is also a likely cause of the fall of Mayan priestly caste, as belief in brutal Mayan rituals fell to the wayside. [PARAGRAPH:2]But the popular notion that the Mayans simply disappeared is false. While the grand temple building, intricate carvings and sacrifices ceased, the Mayan language and people continued to survive in their former homeland, even after the conquest of their country by Spanish conquistadors. The Mayan languages, Yucatec being the most common, are still spoken to this day and armed resistance by the Maya continued into the twentieth century. The Maya remain a living people.
TEXT.French: L'empire maya prospère au milieu des jungles épaisses et des collines volcaniques du Belize, du Guatemala et de la péninsule mexicaine du Yucatan. Fondateurs de la civilisation la plus avancée des Amériques entre 700 av. J.C. et 900 ap. J.C, les Mayas forment à cette époque la deuxième plus grande population du monde, juste après la dynastie chinoise des T'ang.[PARAGRAPH:1]Souvent surnommés les "grecs du nouveau monde", les Mayas sont eux aussi organisés en cités guerrières, même si ces cités servent plus de centres religieux et administratifs que de centres populaires. Les Mayas sont liés par une langue, une religion et un style artistique communs, mais chaque cité demeure férocement indépendante, ne s'unissant souvent qu'au bout de la lance d'un holkan. [PARAGRAPH:1]Chaque cité est gouvernée par sa propre famille royale, qui se réclame souvent d'origine divine ou semi-divine. Au cours de l'ère classique maya, de 250 à 900 ap. J.C. environ, ces cités deviennent de vastes complexes abritant nombre de pyramides, de chaussées et de places. Nakbe, la première cité à connaître un développement de grande ampleur, entame son expansion aux environs de 700 av. J.C. En 300 av. J.C. Nakbe se transforme en une immense ville, pourvue de quatre grandes pyramides et d'une chaussée en pierre de onze kilomètres reliant la ville à la cité voisine de El Mirador.[PARAGRAPH:1]Mais d'autres villes connaissent la même croissance. Chichén Itzá, Tikal et Palenque deviennent toutes d'immenses centres urbains. Dotée d'une myriade de pyramides et de structures religieuses, Tikal devient une ville grandiose et le plus grand centre de population maya, éclipsant même Palenque et Copan.[PARAGRAPH:1]Palenque, petite colonie de l'ouest, atteint son zénith au septième siècle avant J.C. sous le règne de Pacal II qui, en assujettissant les cités voisines, assure l'hégémonie de la sienne. Nous savons beaucoup de choses sur Pacal et sa ville grâce au Temple des inscriptions, dont les murs sont couverts de symboles mayas, lesquels formaient le seul langage écrit développé dans les Amériques.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les mayas n'ont pas excellé que pour le langage. Leurs calendriers étaient presque aussi sophistiqués que ceux de l'ère moderne alors qu'ils ne disposaient ni du télescope ni d'aucun autre outil. L'invention du chiffre zéro, qui avait échappé aux Grecs et aux Romains, est également à mettre sur le compte de l'ingéniosité maya. [PARAGRAPH:1]La plupart de ces découvertes trouvent leur origine dans la religion maya. Même si elle s'intéresse aux nouvelles connaissances, cette dernière croit fortement au pouvoir du sang. De nombreuses guerres sont menées dans le simple but de fournir des prisonniers à sacrifier lors de cérémonies religieuses très complexes, que les Mayas considèrent nécessaires à la sécurité et au développement de leur peuple.[PARAGRAPH:1]La civilisation maya connaît une fin étrangement brusque, dont la cause est encore l'objet de nombreux débats. L'une des théories les plus répandues est que le fragile écosystème des forêts du Yucatan ne pouvait plus soutenir la croissance de la population. Une révolte de paysans pourrait également être à l'origine du déclin de la caste des prêtres, au moment même où la croyance en leurs rites brutaux ne rassemblait plus autant d'adeptes. [PARAGRAPH:1]Mais il serait faut de penser que les Mayas ont disparu. Certes, la construction de temples et la pratique de sacrifices ont cessé, mais la langue et le peuple mayas ont continué à survivre, même après les conquêtes des conquistadors. Les langues mayas (parmi lesquelles la plus courante est le maya yucatèque) sont encore parlées de nos jours et la résistance armée maya se poursuivit jusqu'au vingtième siècle. Les mayas sont toujours un peuple vivant.
TEXT.German: Das Mayareich blühte im dichten Dschungel und auf den Vulkanhügeln von Belize, Guatemala und der mexikanischen Halbinsel Yucatan. Die Maya waren von 700 v. Chr. bis 900 n. Chr. die Schöpfer der fortschrittlichsten Zivilisation auf dem amerikanischen Kontinent, und während ihrer Blütezeit stand die Bevölkerung zahlenmäßig nur der der chinesischen T'ang-Dynastie nach.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Maya werden oft die "Griechen der Neuen Welt" genannt, da sie auf ähnliche Weise in verschiedene einander bekriegende Städte organisiert waren, obwohl diese Städte mehr als religiöse und verwaltungstechnische denn als Bevölkerungszentren dienten. Eine gemeinsame Sprache, Religion und Kunstrichtung einte die Mayakultur, doch jeder Stadtstaat legte großen Wert auf Unabhängigkeit, und oft konnte nur die Spitze eines Holkan-Speers ein Bündnis erzwingen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Jeder Stadtstaat wurde von einer eigenen Königsfamilie regiert, deren Mitglieder oft für sich beanspruchten, Götter oder Halbgötter zu sein. Während der klassischen Epoche der Maya, von etwa 250 bis 900 n. Chr., entwickelten sich diese Städte zu gewaltigen Komplexen mit Pyramiden, Straßen und Plätzen. Nakbe, der erste große Stadtstaat, begann etwa 700 v. Chr. zu expandieren. 300 v. Chr. war aus Nakbe eine beeindruckende Stadt mit vier großen Stufenpyramiden und einer sieben Meilen langen Straße geworden, die sie mit der Nachbarstadt El Mirador verband.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nakbe war nur die erste vieler großer Städte. Chichen Itza, Tikal und Palenque entwickelten sich alle zu großen Bevölkerungszentren. Tikal mit seinen Myriaden an Pyramiden und religiösen Gebäuden entwickelte sich zu einer wahren Großstadt und wurde das größte Bevölkerungszentrum der Maya, demgegenüber Palenque und Copan geradezu klein wirkten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Palenque, eine wesentlich kleinere Siedlung im Westen, erreichte ihre Blütezeit im 7. Jahrhundert n. Chr. unter der Herrschaft Pacals II., der die Nachbarstädte unterjochte, um seine eigene Vorherrschaft zu sichern. Dank der in Pacals Grabmal überlieferten Geschichte wissen wir viel über Pacal und seine Stadt. Im "Tempel der Inschriften" waren ganze Wände mit der typischen Bilderschrift der Maya bedeckt, der einzigen Schriftsprache, die sich auf dem amerikanischen Kontinent entwickelt hat.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Sprachwissenschaft war nicht der einzige Bereich, in dem die Maya hervorragende Leistungen brachten. Ihre Kalender waren nicht nur denen der heutigen Zeit ebenbürtig, sondern wurden ohne die Hilfe von Teleskopen oder anderen Hilfsmitteln geschaffen. Die unabhängige Entwicklung der Zahl Null, eine Leistung, die sowohl die Griechen wie auch die Römer verfehlten, war eine weitere beeindruckende Errungenschaft der Maya.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die meisten dieser Entdeckungen entwickelten sich aus der Religion der Maya. Und obwohl sie sicherlich an Wissen interessiert waren, war die Religion der Maya durchdrungen vom Glauben an die Macht des Blutes. Viele Kriege der Maya wurden einfach geführt, um Gefangene zu machen, die in ausgeklügelten religiösen Zeremonien geopfert wurden, von denen man glaubte, sie wären für die Sicherheit und den Fortschritt der Bevölkerung notwendig.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Zivilisation der Maya erfuhr ein plötzliches Ende, und der Grund für diesen Untergang ist immer noch stark umstritten. Eine der anerkanntesten Theorien besagt, dass die empfindliche Ökologie der Regenwälder in Yucatan die wachsende Bevölkerung der Maya nicht länger ernähren konnte. Auch gilt ein Bauernaufstand als wahrscheinliche Ursache für den Fall der Priesterkaste der Maya, als der Glaube an die brutalen Mayarituale an Kraft verlor.[PARAGRAPH:1]Doch die volkstümliche Anschauung, die Maya wären einfach verschwunden, ist falsch. Obgleich die großartigen Tempelanlagen, feinen Steinmetzarbeiten und die Opferzeremonien nicht mehr existieren, haben die Sprache und das Volk der Maya in ihrer ehemaligen Heimat überlebt und sogar die Eroberung ihres Landes durch die spanischen Konquistadoren überstanden. Die Sprachen der Maya, deren häufigste Yucatec ist, werden noch heute gesprochen, und der bewaffnete Widerstand der Maya dauerte bis in das 20. Jahrhundert an. Die Maya bleiben eine lebendige Kultur.
TEXT.Italian: L'impero maya fiorì nelle fitte giungle e sulle colline vulcaniche di Belize, Guatemala e sulla penisola dello Yucatan in Messico. La popolazione maya rappresentò la civiltà più avanzata in America dal 700 a.C. fino al 900 d.C. e, a suo tempo, fu inferiore come numero solo a quella cinese della dinastia T'ang.[PARAGRAPH:1]Spesso definiti i "Greci del Nuovo Mondo", i Maya erano analogamente organizzati in una serie di città-stato in lotta tra loro, anche se tali città avevano scopi più religiosi e amministrativi che non fungere da centri della popolazione. A unire la cultura maya erano linguaggio, religione e stile artistico comuni, ma ogni città-stato rimaneva fieramente indipendente, spesso unita solo grazie alla punta della lancia di un Holkan. [PARAGRAPH:1]Ogni città-stato era governata dalla propria famiglia reale, che spesso rivendicava una divinità parziale o totale. Durante il periodo classico maya, all'incirca dal 250 al 900 d.C., queste città divennero vasti complessi di piramidi, sentieri rialzati e piazze. Nakbe fu la prima città-stato a crescere molto e cominciò la propria espansione attorno al 700 a.C. Nel 300 a.C. Nakbe si era trasformata in una città impressionante, con quattro piramidi a gradoni e un sentiero in pietra di quasi dodici chilometri che la collegava alla vicina città di El Mirador. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nakbe fu solo la prima di molte città immense. Chichen Itza, Tikal e Palenque divennero tutte grossi centri urbani. Con miriadi di piramidi e strutture religiose, Tikal crebbe fino a diventare la città più importante e il maggiore fra i centri popolati dei Maya, ancor più di Palenque e Copan.[PARAGRAPH:1]Palenque, un insediamento decisamente più piccolo a ovest, raggiunse il massimo splendore nel settimo secolo d.C. sotto il regno di Pakal II, che sottomise le città circostanti assicurando l'egemonia della propria. Molto si sa di Pakal e della sua città grazie alla storia incisa all'interno della sua tomba, il "Tempio delle Iscrizioni". Al suo interno, interi muri erano ricoperti con la caratteristica scrittura pittografica dei Maya, l'unico linguaggio scritto mai sviluppato in America. [PARAGRAPH:1]Il linguaggio non era l'unico campo in cui le menti dei Maya eccellevano. I loro calendari sono quasi al livello di quelli odierni ma furono creati senza l'uso di telescopi o altri strumenti. La scoperta indipendente del numero zero, cosa che sfuggì a Greci e Romani, è un'altra delle impressionanti imprese dei Maya. [PARAGRAPH:1]La maggior parte di queste scoperte è da imputare alla religione Maya. E, pur essendo interessati alla conoscenza, la loro religione era basata sulla fede nel potere del sangue. Molte guerre tra i Maya furono combattute semplicemente con lo scopo di ottenere prigionieri da sacrificare in complesse cerimonie religiose, che si pensava fossero necessarie per assicurare la salvezza e il progresso. [PARAGRAPH:1]La civiltà Maya ebbe una fine brusca e prematura e il motivo è ancora fonte di dibattito. Una delle teorie più diffuse è che la delicata ecologia delle foreste dello Yucatan non riuscì più a sopportare la popolazione in aumento della civiltà maya. Anche la rivolta dei contadini potrebbe essere una causa verosimile della caduta della casta dei preti maya, per via di una diminuzione della fede nei brutali rituali maya. [PARAGRAPH:1]Ma la diffusa credenza che il popolo maya sia veramente scomparso è falsa. Gli enormi templi, i complessi geroglifici e i sacrifici sono terminati, ma la lingua e il popolo maya continuano a sopravvivere nella loro vecchia patria, anche dopo la conquista del loro Paese da parte dei conquistatori spagnoli. Lo Yucatec è il più diffuso tra gli idiomi maya, molti dei quali sono parlati ancora oggi, e la resistenza armata dei Maya è continuata fino al ventesimo secolo. I Maya rimangono un popolo vivo.
TEXT.Spanish: El imperio maya floreció en las densas selvas y las colinas volcánicas de Belice, Guatemala y la península del Yucatán, en México. Creadores de la más avanzada civilización americana desde el 700 a. C. al 900 d. C., los mayas de aquel tiempo solo eran superados en número por la dinastía china de los T'ang.[PARAGRAPH:1]Los mayas, descritos en numerosas ocasiones como los "griegos del nuevo mundo" estaban organizados, al igual que éstos, en una serie de ciudades-estado rivales. No obstante, en este caso, el término "ciudad" hace más referencia a un centro administrativo y religioso que a una unidad poblacional. Los elementos que unificaban la cultura maya eran una lengua, una religión y un estilo artístico comunes, pero cada ciudad-estado defendía celosamente su independencia y normalmente solo se unían por la fuerza. [PARAGRAPH:1]Cada ciudad-estado contaba con su propia familia real, que a menudo se atribuía una condición divina o semidivina. Durante el período maya clásico (250-900 d. C. aproximadamente), estas ciudades se convirtieron en vastos complejos de pirámides, avenidas y plazas. Nakbe, la primera ciudad-estado que alcanzó unas dimensiones importantes, inició su expansión alrededor del año 700 a. C. Hacia el año 300 a. C., Nakbe se había transformado en una impresionante metrópolis, con cuatro grandes pirámides escalonadas y una avenida de más de diez kilómetros de longitud para comunicarse con la cercana ciudad de El Mirador. [PARAGRAPH:1]Nakbe fue solo la primera de numerosas metrópolis. Chichen Itzá, Tikal y Palenque llegaron a ser enormes centros poblacionales. Con una miríada de pirámides y templos, Tikal se convirtió en una ciudad colosal, el mayor de los centros urbanos mayas, capaz de empequeñecer incluso a Palenque y a Copan.[PARAGRAPH:1]Palenque, un asentamiento occidental considerablemente más modesto, alcanzó su cúspide en el siglo VII d. C., bajo el reinado de Pacal II, que aseguró la hegemonía de su ciudad sometiendo a las vecinas. Sabemos muchas cosas sobre Pacal y su ciudad gracias a la intrincada historia tallada que decora el interior de su tumba, conocida como "El templo de las Inscripciones". Hay en esta estructura paredes enteras grabadas con la característica lengua pictográfica de los mayas, el único idioma escrito desarrollado en América. [PARAGRAPH:1]El lingüístico no fue el único campo en el que descollaron los mayas. Sus calendarios eran realmente comparables con los de la era moderna, solo que estaban elaborados sin el uso de telescopios u otras herramientas. La invención del número cero, un logro matemático que se les había resistido tanto a los griegos como a los romanos, fue otra proeza de los mayas. [PARAGRAPH:1]La mayoría de estos descubrimientos surgieron de la religión maya. Esta religión, aunque interesada en el conocimiento, se caracterizaba sobre todo por su fe en el poder de la sangre. Muchas de las guerras de los mayas se libraron con el solo objetivo de obtener prisioneros para sacrificar en sus complejas ceremonias religiosas, consideradas necesarias para garantizar la seguridad y el progreso del pueblo. [PARAGRAPH:1]La civilización maya sufrió un fin sorprendentemente repentino, cuya causa es aún hoy objeto de acalorados debates. Una de las teorías que concita más unanimidad es la que cree que la delicada ecología de las selvas del Yucatán no pudo sustentar la creciente población de los pueblos mayas. También es probable que se produjera una revuelta popular para derribar la casta sacerdotal, provocada por el declive de la fe en sus sanguinarios rituales. [PARAGRAPH:1]Pero la idea, bastante extendida, de que los mayas desaparecieron sin más es sencillamente falsa. Aunque la construcción de grandes templos, la práctica de las tallas y los sacrificios rituales desaparecieran, la lengua y el pueblo maya continuaron viviendo en sus tierras aun después de la llegada de los conquistadores españoles. Las lenguas mayas, de las cuales la más extendida era el yucateca, siguen hablándose en nuestros días, y la resistencia armada de los aborígenes mayas se prolongó hasta el siglo XX. El pueblo maya, en suma, sigue existiendo.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Highly developed cultures, including those of the Olmecs, Mayas, Toltecs, and Aztecs, existed long before the Spanish conquest. Hernando Cortes conquered Mexico during the period 1519-21 and founded a Spanish colony that lasted nearly 300 years.[PARAGRAPH:2]Independence from Spain was proclaimed by Father Miguel Hidalgo on September 16, 1810. Father Hidalgo's declaration of national independence, known in Mexico as the "Grito de Dolores", launched a decade long struggle for independence from Spain. Prominent figures in Mexico's war for independence were Father Jose Maria Morelos; Gen. Augustin de Iturbide, who defeated the Spaniards and ruled as Mexican emperor from 1822-23; and Gen. Antonio Lopez de Santa Ana, who went on to dominate Mexican politics from 1833 to 1855. An 1821 treaty recognized Mexican independence from Spain and called for a constitutional monarchy. The planned monarchy failed; a republic was proclaimed in December 1822 and established in 1824.[PARAGRAPH:2]Throughout the rest of the 19th century, Mexico's government and economy were shaped by contentious debates among liberals and conservatives, republicans and monarchists, federalists and those who favored centralized government. During the two presidential terms of Benito Juarez (1858-71), Mexico experimented with modern democratic and economic reforms. President Juarez' terms of office, and Mexico's early experience with democracy, were interrupted by the Habsburg monarchy's rule of Mexico (1864-67), and was followed by the authoritarian government of Gen. Porfirio Diaz, who was president during most of the period between 1877 and 1911.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mexico's severe social and economic problems erupted in a revolution that lasted from 1910-20 and gave rise to the 1917 constitution. Prominent leaders in this period (some of whom were rivals for power) were Francisco Madero, Venustiano Carranza, Pancho Villa, Alvaro Obregon, Victoriano Huerta, and Emiliano Zapata. The Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI), formed in 1929 under a different name, emerged from the chaos of revolution as a vehicle for keeping political competition among a coalition of interests in peaceful channels. For 71 years, Mexico's national government was controlled by the PRI, which won every presidential race and most gubernatorial races until the July 2000 presidential election of Vicente Fox Quesada of the National Action Party (PAN).

[TAB]The term Moors has referred to several historic and modern populations of Berber, Black African and Arab descent from Northern Africa, who came to conquer, occupy and rule the Iberian Peninsula for nearly 800 years. At that time they were Muslim, although earlier the people had followed other religions. They called the territory Al Andalus, comprising most of what is now Spain and Portugal.[PARAGRAPH:1]Moors are not a distinct or self-defined people. Medieval and early modern Europeans applied the name primarily to Berbers, but also at various times to Arabs, Muslim Iberians and West Africans from Mali and Niger who had been absorbed into the Almoravid dynasty. Mainstream scholars observed in 1911 that "The term 'Moors' has no real ethnological value."[PARAGRAPH:1]The Andalusian Moors of the late Medieval era inhabited the Iberian Peninsula after the Moorish conquests of the Rashidun and Umayyad Caliphates, and the final Umayyad conquest of Hispania. The Moors' rule stretched at times as far as modern-day Mauritania, West African countries, and the Senegal River. Earlier, the Classical Romans interacted with (and later conquered) parts of Mauretania, a state that covered northern portions of modern Morocco and much of north western and central Algeria during the classical period. The people of the region were noted in Classical literature as the Mauri.[PARAGRAPH:1]The term Mauri, or variations, was later used by European traders and explorers of the 16th to 18th centuries to designate ethnic Berber and Arab groups speaking the Hassaniya Arabic dialect.[citation needed] Today such groups inhabit Mauritania and parts of Algeria, western Sahara, Morocco, Niger and Mali. Speakers of European languages have historically designated a number of associated ethnic groups as "Moors". In modern Iberia, the term is applied to people of Moroccan ethnicity living in Europe. "Moor" is sometimes colloquially applied to any person from North Africa. Some people to whom it is applied consider the term pejorative and racist.

[TAB]The Mughal Empire was an Indian-Islamic imperial power that ruled a large portion of the Indian subcontinent which began in 1526, invaded and ruled most of South Asia by the late 17th and early 18th centuries by forming alliance with Indian Maharaja, and ended in the mid-19th century. The Mughal Emperors were descendants of the Timurids, and at the height of their power around 1700, they controlled most of the Indian Subcontinent extending from Bengal in the east to Balochistan in the west, Kashmir in the north to the Kaveri basin in the south. Its population at that time has been estimated as between 110 and 130 million, over a territory of over 4 million sq.km (1.5 million square miles).[PARAGRAPH:2]The "classic period" of the Empire started in 1556 with the accession of Jalaluddin Mohammad Akbar, better known as Akbar the Great. It ended with the death of Emperor Aurangzeb in 1707, although the Empire continued for another 150 years. During this period, the Empire was marked by a highly centralized administration connecting the different regions. All the significant monuments of the Mughals, their most visible legacy, date to this period which was characterised by the expansion of Persian cultural influence in the Indian subcontinent, with brilliant literary, artistic and architectural results.[PARAGRAPH:2]Following 1725 the empire declined rapidly, weakened by wars of succession, agrarian crises fueling local revolts, the growth of religious intolerance, the rise of the Maratha, Durrani, and Sikh empires and finally British colonialism. The last king, Bahadur Zafar Shah II, whose rule was restricted to the city of Delhi, was imprisoned and exiled by the British after the Indian Rebellion of 1857.[PARAGRAPH:2]The name Mughal is derived from the original homelands of the Timurids, the Central Asian steppes once conquered by Genghis Khan and hence known as Moghulistan, "Land of Mongols". Although early Mughals spoke the Chagatai language and maintained Turko-Mongol practices, they were essentially Persianized. They transferred the Persian literature and culture to India, thus forming the base for the Indo-Persian culture.

[TAB]Originally several separate territories under the control of the Holy Roman Empire, and then united into one state under Habsburg rule (16th century), the Netherlands did not acquire national independence until the conclusion of the Eighty Years' War (1568-1648 AD) when the Spanish formally renounced all claims to Dutch sovereignty in the Treaty of Münster.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Eighty Years' War was sparked by Spanish religious oppression and an occupation by Spanish forces led by the Duke of Alba, during which over one thousand people were sentenced to death, including two prominent and popular Dutch nobles; these actions caused dissention among the Dutch people. In 1568 Willem, Prince of Orange, returned from a self-imposed exile (in order to avoid prosecution by the Duke of Alba) and led the uprising against the Spanish occupation.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Dutch fight for independence can be seen as a war against religious oppression, with the Pacification of Ghent treaty being a written representation of this sentiment. Signed on November 8th, 1576 the document specified an alliance between the Dutch provinces, in which religious differences would be put aside for the purposes of expelling the Spanish and restoring local provincial control to the Netherlands.[PARAGRAPH:2]During the seventeenth century the Dutch began using their large military and merchant navies to both create their own trading posts along the African coast and rob those of the Portuguese in an effort to reach valuable markets in India and Indonesia. The inrush of treasure, trade and knowledge from these trading and military expeditions was extremely beneficial, and during this first half of the seventeenth century the Dutch experienced a Golden Age of cultural and economic growth. This Golden Age would soon come to a crushing end.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1795, France, under Napoleon I, conquered the Dutch mainland. The Netherlands quickly declined in influence and power, locally and internationally, with the British taking most of their colonial possessions. After Napoleon was defeated a few colonial territories were restored to the Dutch and remained under their control until the decolonization of the twentieth century.[PARAGRAPH:2]Many historians regard the Dutch empire as the first truly capitalist country. In addition to developing the first stock exchange, many modern services such as corporate insurance and retirement funds were attributed to Dutch inventiveness.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Netherlands is also the birthplace of one of the world's early democratic institutions - the Dutch Water Boards. Due to the unique topography of the Netherlands - about half of the mainland is a foot or more under sea level - the country's waterways must be constantly monitored and controlled in order to prevent flooding that would result in tremendous loss of life and property. Each Water Board is in charge of one of the nation's 27 water districts and all matters pertaining to local water management. The creation of these water boards predates the Netherlands itself. [PARAGRAPH:2]The modern Netherlands, with a diverse population and liberal laws towards drugs, prostitution, abortion, same-sex marriage, and euthanasia, has been a constant haven for refugees from other countries. Cultural minorities are encouraged to protect their own cultural identity while at the same time integrate into Dutch culture at large, further reinforcing the open-minded ideals for which Dutch ancestors fought and died.
TEXT.French: A l'origine, les Pays-Bas étaient constitués de plusieurs territoires, d'abord séparés sous le contrôle du Saint Empire romain germanique, puis unifiés sous le règne des Habsbourg (16ème siècle). Les Pays-Bas n'acquièrent leur indépendance qu'à la fin de la Guerre de quatre-vingts ans (1568-1648) quand les Espagnols renoncent officiellement à toute prétention sur la souveraineté néerlandaise en signant le Traité de Münster.[PARAGRAPH:1]La Guerre de quatre-vingts ans est déclenchée par l'oppression religieuse Espagnole et par l'occupation des troupes hispaniques (menées par le duc d'Albe), au cours de laquelle plus de mille personnes sont condamnées à mort, y compris deux membres importants de la noblesse néerlandaise, provoquant le soulèvement du peuple néerlandais. En 1568, Guillaume, prince d'Orange, revient d'un exil qu'il s'était lui-même imposé (afin d'éviter d'être poursuivi par le duc d'Albe) et mène la révolte contre l'occupation espagnole.[PARAGRAPH:1] La lutte néerlandaise pour l'indépendance peut être considérée comme une guerre contre le sentiment d'oppression religieuse, sentiment dont le traité de Pacification de Gand sera la représentation écrite. Ce document, signé le 8 novembre 1576, consacre une alliance entre les provinces néerlandaises, au sein de laquelle les différents religieux seront mis de côté afin de chasser les espagnols et de restaurer un contrôle local sur les Pays-Bas.[PARAGRAPH:1]Au cours du 17ème siècle, les néerlandais commencent à utiliser leurs vastes marines militaires et marchandes pour créer leurs propres postes de commerce le long de la côte Africaine et piller les comptoirs portugais, afin d'atteindre les précieux marchés d'Inde et d'Indonésie. Les revenus financiers, commerciaux et scientifiques de ces expéditions commerciales et militaires sont extrêmement substantiels et, durant la première moitié du dix-septième siècle, les néerlandais connaissent un âge d'or provoqué par une forte croissance économique et culturelle. Cet âge d'or doit bientôt s'achever dans le sang.[PARAGRAPH:1]En 1795 la France, sous Napoléon Ier, conquiert les Pays-Bas continentaux. Les Pays-Bas perdent rapidement pouvoir et influence, localement et mondialement, tandis que les Anglais s'emparent de leurs possessions coloniales. Après la défaite de Napoléon, quelques colonies sont rendues aux Néerlandais et demeurent sous leur contrôle jusqu'à la décolonisation du vingtième siècle.[PARAGRAPH:1]De nombreux historiens considèrent l'empire néerlandais comme le premier pays réellement capitaliste. En plus de la première Bourse, de nombreux services modernes comme les assurances et les fonds de retraite sont attribués à l'innovation néerlandaise.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les Pays-bas sont aussi la patrie de l'une des premières institutions démocratiques mondiales : les Conseils de l'eau néerlandais. En raison de la topographie unique des Pays-Bas (environ la moitié du continent est située trente centimètres ou plus au-dessous du niveau de la mer), les voies navigables doivent être constamment surveillées et contrôlées afin d'éviter une inondation qui provoquerait des pertes humaines et matérielles considérables. Chaque Conseil de l'eau est responsable de l'une des 27 agences de l'eau de la nation et de toutes les affaires relatives à la gestion de l'eau. La création de ces Conseils de l'eau précède celle des Pays-bas eux-mêmes. [PARAGRAPH:1]Avec une population très diversifiée et des lois libérales concernant les drogues, la prostitution, l'avortement, le mariage homosexuel et l'euthanasie, les Pays-Bas modernes sont toujours une destination de prédilection pour les réfugiés. Le gouvernement néerlandais encourage les minorités à protéger leur propre identité culturelle tout en intégrant la culture néerlandaise dans son ensemble, renforçant ainsi davantage les idéaux d'ouverture pour lesquels les ancêtres néerlandais se sont battus jusqu'à la mort.
TEXT.German: Die Niederlande, ehemals sieben unabhängige Territorien unter der Herrschaft des Heiligen Römischen Reiches, die unter habsburgischer Herrschaft (16. Jahrhundert) vereint wurden, erreichten ihre nationale Unabhängigkeit erst mit dem Ende des Achtzigjährigen Krieges (1568 - 1648 n. Chr.), als die Spanier im Vertrag von Münster offiziell auf alle Ansprüche an Holland verzichteten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Der Achtzigjährige Krieg entbrannte aufgrund religiöser Verfolgung durch Spanien und der Besetzung durch spanische Truppen unter der Führung des Herzogs von Alba, während derer über tausend Menschen zum Tode verurteilt wurden, darunter zwei beliebte holländische Adlige. Diese Ereignisse schürten Unzufriedenheit beim holländischen Volk. 1568 kehrte Wilhelm, Prinz von Oranien, aus einem selbst auferlegten Exil zurück (auf diese Weise war er der Verfolgung durch den Herzog von Alba entgangen) und führte den Aufstand gegen die spanische Besatzung an.[PARAGRAPH:1]Der holländische Kampf um Unabhängigkeit kann als Krieg gegen religiöse Unterdrückung gesehen werden, von der das Vertragswerk der Genter Pazifikation ein schriftliches Zeugnis bietet. Das Dokument, das am 8. November 1576 unterzeichnet wurde, stellt ein Bündnis holländischer Provinzen her, für das zum Zweck der Vertreibung der Spanier und der Wiederherstellung der örtlichen Provinzregierung in den Niederlanden die religiösen Differenzen zur Seite gelegt werden sollten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Während des 17. Jahrhunderts begannen die Holländer, ihre großen Kriegs- und Handelsflotten zu nutzen, um sowohl eigene Handelsposten entlang der afrikanischen Küste zu errichten als auch die der Portugiesen zu plündern und wertvolle Märkte in Indien und Indonesien zu erreichen. Der Zustrom von Reichtum, Handel und Wissen aus diesen Handels- und Kriegsexpeditionen wirkte sich äußerst günstig aus, und während der ersten Hälfte des 17. Jahrhunderts erlebten die Holländer eine Blütezeit der Wirtschaft und Kultur. Dieses Goldene Zeitalter sollte jedoch bald ein schreckliches Ende erfahren.[PARAGRAPH:1]1795 eroberte Frankreich unter Napoleon I. das holländische Festland. Die Niederlande verloren rasch an Einfluss und Macht, vor Ort und international, während die Briten Besitz vom Großteil ihrer Kolonien ergriffen. Nachdem Napoleon besiegt worden war, erhielten die Holländer einige wenige Kolonien zurück, die sie bis zur Dekolonisierung im 20. Jahrhundert behielten.[PARAGRAPH:1]Viele Historiker betrachten das Niederländische Reich als den ersten echten kapitalistischen Stadt. Außer der Entwicklung der ersten Börse werden dem holländischen Erfindungsgeist viele moderne Dienstleistungen wie Unternehmensversicherungen und Pensionskassen zugeschrieben.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die Niederlande sind auch der Geburtsort einer der ältesten demokratischen Einrichtungen der Welt - der Holländischen Wasserverwaltung. Aufgrund der einzigartigen Topografie der Niederlande - etwa die Hälfte des Festlands liegt 30 cm oder mehr unter dem Meeresspiegel - müssen die Wasserwege des Landes ständig überwacht und kontrolliert werden, um Fluten zu vermeiden, die einen immensen Verlust an Menschenleben und Besitz zur Folge hätten. Jede Wasserverwaltung ist für eines der 27 nationalen Wassergebiete und alle mit der örtlichen Wasserverwaltung zusammenhängenden Angelegenheiten zuständig. Diese Wasserverwaltungsgremien sind bereits älter als die Niederlande selbst.[PARAGRAPH:1]Die modernen Niederlande mit ihrer vielfältigen Bevölkerung und der liberalen Gesetzgebung in Sachen Drogen, Prostitution, Abtreibung, gleichgeschlechtlicher Ehe und Sterbehilfe, sind ein ständiger Hafen für Flüchtlinge aus anderen Ländern. Kulturelle Minderheiten werden darin bestärkt, ihre eigene kulturelle Identität zu wahren und sich gleichzeitig in die allgemeine holländische Kultur zu integrieren; eine Haltung, welche die toleranten und offenen Ideale bestärkt, für die die holländischen Vorfahren gekämpft und ihr Leben gegeben haben.
TEXT.Italian: Inizialmente i Paesi Bassi erano territori separati sotto il controllo del Sacro Romano Impero e vennero uniti in un unico stato sotto la guida degli Asburgo (XIV secolo) ma non acquisirono una propria indipendenza fino alla fine della Guerra degli 80 anni (1568-1648 d.C.), quando la Spagna rinunciò formalmente a tutte le pretese sulla sovranità olandese, con il Trattato di Münster.[PARAGRAPH:1]La Guerra degli 80 anni fu scatenata dall'oppressione religiosa da parte degli spagnoli e dall'occupazione di forze iberiche guidate dal Duca d'Alba, durante la quale mille persone furono condannate a morte, tra cui due nobili olandesi prominenti e popolari; queste azioni causarono il dissenso della popolazione olandese. Nel 1568 Guglielmo, principe d'Orange, tornò da un esilio autoimposto (per evitare la persecuzione del Duca d'Alba) e guidò la rivolta contro l'occupazione spagnola.[PARAGRAPH:1]La lotta olandese per l'indipendenza può essere vista come una guerra contro l'oppressione religiosa e la Pacificazione di Gand la rappresentazione scritta di tale sentimento. Firmato l'8 novembre del 1576, questo documento stabiliva un'alleanza tra le province olandesi in cui le differenze religiose venivano messe da parte per cercare di cacciare gli spagnoli e di ripristinare il controllo provinciale locale dei Paesi Bassi.[PARAGRAPH:1]Durante il diciassettesimo secolo gli olandesi cominciarono a utilizzare la propria marina mercantile e militare sia per creare delle stazioni commerciali lungo le coste africane sia per derubare quelle portoghesi, nel tentativo di raggiungere i preziosi mercati in India e Indonesia. L'afflusso di tesori, commercio e conoscenza derivanti da queste spedizioni militari e commerciali ebbe un effetto estremamente positivo e, durante la prima metà del diciassettesimo secolo, gli olandesi conobbero un periodo di grande crescita culturale ed economica. Un'età dell'oro che sarebbe presto tragicamente terminata.[PARAGRAPH:1]Nel 1795 la Francia, sotto Napoleone I, conquistò l'Olanda. I Paesi Bassi persero rapidamente influenza e potere, sia a livello locale sia internazionale, e i britannici presero la maggior parte dei loro possedimenti coloniali. Dopo la sconfitta di Napoleone alcuni territori coloniali tornarono agli olandesi e rimasero sotto il loro controllo fino alla decolonizzazione del ventesimo secolo.[PARAGRAPH:1]Molti storici vedono l'impero olandese come il primo paese realmente capitalista. Oltre ad aver sviluppato la prima borsa azionaria, molti altri servizi moderni come le assicurazioni aziendali e i fondi di pensionamento sono da imputare all'inventività olandese.[PARAGRAPH:1]I Paesi Bassi sono anche il luogo di nascita di una delle prime istituzioni democratiche al mondo: i Distretti di Controllo delle Acque (Water Boards). A causa dell'insolita topografia del Paese, circa una metà dei Paesi Bassi è di una trentina di centimetri al di sotto del livello del mare: i corsi d'acqua devono essere costantemente controllati per prevenire allagamenti che causerebbero perdite di vite e di proprietà. Ogni distretto si occupa di una delle 27 aree in cui è diviso il Paese e di tutti i problemi inerenti alla gestione locale delle acque. La creazione di tali distretti è antecedente a quella degli stessi Paesi Bassi. [PARAGRAPH:1]I moderni Paesi Bassi, con una popolazione eterogenea e leggi liberali su droga, prostituzione, aborto, matrimoni tra persone dello stesso sesso ed eutanasia accolgono da sempre rifugiati da altri Paesi. Le minoranze culturali sono incoraggiate a difendere la propria identità culturale, pur integrandosi ampiamente nella cultura olandese, rinforzando in questo modo gli ideali di larghe vedute per cui gli antenati olandesi combatterono e morirono.
TEXT.Spanish: Holanda, que originariamente solo era varios territorios separados bajo el control del Sacro Imperio Romano y más tarde unificados en un solo estado bajo el dominio de los Habsburgo (siglo XVI), no alcanzó la independencia hasta el final de la Guerra de los Ochenta Años (1568-1648), cuando, en el tratado de Münster, los españoles renunciaron finalmente a sus pretensiones de soberanía sobre ella.[PARAGRAPH:1]Lo que desencadenó la Guerra de los Ochenta Años fue la intolerancia religiosa de los españoles y la ocupación del país por parte de las fuerzas del duque de Alba, que sentenció a muerte a un millar de personas, incluidos dos importantes y populares nobles. Estos actos provocaron el descontento del pueblo. En 1568, Guillermo, príncipe de Orange, regresó del exilio que él mismo se había impuesto (para no caer en manos del Duque de Alba) y se puso a la cabeza de la revuelta.[PARAGRAPH:1]La lucha por la independencia de los holandeses puede verse como una guerra contra la opresión religiosa, sentimiento encarnado en la llamada Pacificación de Gante. Firmado el 8 de noviembre de 1576, este documento establecía una alianza entre las diferentes provincias holandesas, cuyas diferencias religiosas serían apartadas con el fin de expulsar a los españoles y recuperar la autonomía.[PARAGRAPH:1]A lo largo del siglo XVII, los holandeses empezaron a utilizar sus grandes barcos mercantes y de guerra para establecer puestos comerciales a lo largo de la costa africana y asaltar los de los portugueses, en un intento por alcanzar los ricos mercados de la India e Indonesia. La llegada de riquezas, mercancías y conocimientos generado por estas expediciones comerciales y militares fue extremadamente beneficio y, durante la primera mitad del siglo XVII, los holandeses vivieron una edad dorada de crecimiento cultural y económico. Esta edad de oro no tardaría en sufrir un fin dolorosamente brusco.[PARAGRAPH:1]En 1795, los ejércitos franceses de Napoleón I conquistaron la metrópolis holandesa. Holanda experimentó un acusado declive en su influencia y poder, tanto local como internacionalmente, y los británicos se apoderaron de la mayor parte de sus colonias. Tras la derrota de Napoleón, algunos de los territorios coloniales fueron devueltos a los holandeses, y permanecieron bajo su control hasta el proceso descolonizador del siglo XX.[PARAGRAPH:1]Muchos historiadores consideran al imperio holandés el primer estado realmente capitalista. Además de desarrollar la primera bolsa de la historia, muchas instituciones modernas, como los seguros corporativos y los fondos de pensiones, se consideran inventos holandeses.[PARAGRAPH:1]Holanda fue también el escenario de la aparición de una de las primeras instituciones democráticas del mundo: las Juntas del agua. Debido a las especiales características topográficas de Holanda (casi la mitad del país está más de treinta centímetros por debajo del nivel del mar), los ríos deben ser objeto de vigilancia y control constantes para prevenir inundaciones y pérdidas catastróficas. Cada Junta del agua controla uno de los 27 distritos hidrográficos del país, y gestiona todo lo referente a los recursos hídricos. La creación de estas instituciones es anterior al nacimiento del propio estado de Holanda. [PARAGRAPH:1]La moderna Holanda, con su población cosmopolita y su legislación liberal con respecto a las drogas, la prostitución, el aborto, los matrimonios homosexuales y la eutanasia, ha sido un auténtico paraíso para refugiados procedentes de otras regiones. Se alienta a las minorías a proteger su identidad cultural, al tiempo que se integran en la cultura holandesa en su conjunto, lo que contribuye a reforzar los ideales de tolerancia por los que lucharon y murieron los antepasados de los holandeses.

TEXT.English: [TAB]There can be little doubt that, had they been able to overcome their internal divisions, the Poles would have been a dominant power in the Middle Ages. The first institution that can be called a Polish kingdom or nation arose in around 980 AD, when a tribal leader named Mieszko united three major tribes in eastern Europe and converted to Catholicism. The concept of a dynasty had not yet caught on in that part of Europe, though, so successions were often extremely violent and chaotic. After Mieszko's rule, the fortunes of the Polish nation-state depended entirely on the ruthlessness and strength of will of its leader. Some of Mieszko's successors were strong and able to impose their wills on the fractious principalities and tribes of Poland and Pomerania, and thereby defend effectively against foreign, usually German or Bohemian, invasion. Others were not.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1226 AD, just over two hundred years after Boleslaw II successfully reunited the Polish kingdom, Poland was deeply divided once again. Baltic tribes menaced the north and the German state of Brandenburg sought greater land and influence in the west. The Polish king, Conrad of Mazovia, decided to import an army to fight off both of these threats in exchange for an indefinite homeland in Poland. The army was the Teutonic Knights. They accepted Conrad's offer and, after arriving in northern Poland, waged several bloody campaigns of conquest against the German and Baltic occupiers. To Conrad's surprise, though, the Knights then decided that they would rather have their own country rather than a dependent homeland inside someone else's kingdom. Conrad had saved the Polish kingdom from outside invasion, only to be invaded from within.[PARAGRAPH:2]Future Polish kings then had to deal not just with Germans, Bohemians and Lithuanians, but the restless and aggressive Teutonic Knights. As if that were not enough, in 1241 a major Mongol invasion force arrived in Silesia (southeastern Poland). The Poles were able to defeat the Mongols, but at huge cost. Vast lands were laid waste and thousands of soldiers perished. In 1330 tensions between the Teutonic Knights and Poland erupted into open war, and after many political and military stalemates, the Polish king Casimir III was able to expand and recover from the Mongol attack and the endless conflicts with Poland's neighbors. But despite holding firm, Casimir had to settle for survival rather than prosperity.[PARAGRAPH:2]The golden age of Poland came at the end of the Middle Ages, when alliance with Lithuania led to a combined assault on the Teutonic Knights that culminated in the fated battle of Grunwald in 1410. The Knights were able to fight off one contingent of the allied force, but were crushed by the other. The Knights were not totally defeated, but they would never again exert their will upon Poland as forcefully as they had in the preceding two centuries. Casimir IV, perhaps the greatest Polish king, was able to capitalize on this success to unite the Polish succession lines with those of Hungary and Bohemia, creating, albeit briefly, an eastern European super-state that dominated the region culturally and militarily for two generations.
